title: Managerial Negotiations in the Workplace
headline: Free online course on managerial negotiations and the components of interpersonal dynamics at the workplace.
description: This free online course on managerial negotiations in the workplace provides a comprehensive guide on how to carry out effective negotiations within the work environment. Learn about the negative impact of anger, anxiety, as well as depression in the workplace. Learn also how to manage employees' expectations so as to enhance their productivity as well as organizational synergy. Begin this course today and improve your negotiation skills.

courseDescription:
This free online course on managerial negotiation in the workplace will begin by introducing you to the concept of ego defense and group dynamics as an important aspect of relationship development. You will learn how to maintain professional relationships with both your superiors as well as your subordinates. You will be provided with the requisite knowledge of how employee-organization relationships are formed.
This course will then introduce you to the meaning and importance of emotional negotiation in the workplace as well as the temporal phases of emotional bargaining. You will learn how to incorporate emotional bargaining for official purposes. You will also learn about the different approaches to emotional negotiation, the effective negotiating strategies for negotiation, and how to apply them to workplace negotiation.
Finally, this course will introduce you to the causes as well as the effects of anger, anxiety, and depression in the workplace. You will learn the most effective way to manage conflict resolution within an organization so that it does not affect morale. You will then learn about the concept of expectation along with the ways to manage employees' expectations so as to enable them to perform optimally without recourse to whether their expectations will be met or not.

Start Course Now

Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:

Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:

  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Ego Defense Mechanism and Emotional Negotiation
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept of Ego Defense Mechanism and Group Dynamics, dyadic relationships at work, emotional negotiation, anger, anxiety, and depression. You will learn about the different theories of group dynamics and group counseling. You will also learn how to maintain work relationships, as well as the concept of dyadic relationships, the five-step approach for emotional negotiation, and the causes of depression and how it can be treated
topics: Ego Defense Mechanism and Emotional Negotiation - Learning Outcomes
Anxiety and Depression: Causes and Treatment
Ego Defense Mechanism and Emotional Negotiation - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Expectations, Thinking Process and Managerial Flexibility
modules.description: In this module, you will be introduced to the concept of expectations, thinking process, managerial flexibility, and reinstating relationships. You will learn about the difference between positive and negative aspects of low expectations and the elements of your thought process. You will also learn about the elements of managerial flexibility and the effective ways of resolving relationship problems.
topics: Expectations, Thinking Process and Managerial Flexibility - Learning Outcomes
Expectations, Thinking Process and Managerial Flexibility - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
topics: Managerial Negotiations in the Workplace - Course Assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Discuss the concept of ego defense mechanism and group dynamics.
    • Explain the different theories of group dynamics.
    • Define workplace relationships.
    • Discuss the concept of dyadic relationships.
    • Discuss the importance of emotion in negotiation.
    • Identify the five-step approach for emotional negotiation.
    • Explain the Indian's negotiating strategies and tactical ways.
    • Discuss the effect of communication medium on negotiation.
    • Discuss the concept of anger, anxiety, and depression.
    • Explain the causes of anger, anxiety, and depression. 
    • Identify the types of anger and anxiety.
    • Discuss anger management and treatment.

  • Lesson Summary
    • A defense mechanism is an unconscious strategy brought to play by various entities to cope with reality and to maintain self-image. The ego defense mechanism, therefore, is the moderator between the id and the superego which seeks compromises to pacify both. It can be viewed as our sense of time and space.
    • The id, ego, and superego work together to create human behavior. 
    • Work relationships refer to patterns of exchange between two interacting members or partners, whether individuals, groups, or organizations, typically directed at the accomplishment of some common goals or objectives.
    • A dyadic work relationship is a relationship between a superior and a subordinate at work. It comes in the form of leader-member exchange, employee-organization relationships, mentoring, and social networking. 
    • The approaches to emotional negotiation are affect-and-cognition and social function approach.
    • Indian negotiation strategies and tactical ways include the teachings of Bhagavad Gita, who teaches that one should be detached so as not to be clouded by desires.
    • Anger is an emotion related to one's psychological interpretation of having been offended, wronged, or denied, and a tendency to react through retaliation. Anger can be aggressive or passive.
    • Anxiety is an unpleasant state of inner turmoil, often accompanied by nervous behavior such as pacing back and forth, somatic complaints, and rumination. It is subjectively an unpleasant feeling of dread over something unlikely to happen.

The ego defense mechanism, therefore, is the moderator between the id and the superego which seeks compromises to pacify both. It can be viewed as our sense of time and space.

  • Learning Outcomes
  • Upon the successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Distinguish between the positive and negative aspects of low expectation,
    • Explain how expectations can be managed.
    • Discuss the concepts of thinking and thinking process.
    • Identify types of thinking, and the level of thinking.
    • Analyze the concept of organizational flexibility.
    • Explain the elements and types of managerial flexibility.
    • Discuss the dimension of human resource flexibility.
    • Identify the common reasons for relationship building.
    • Discuss the different approaches to relationship building.
    • Describe the factors that lead to relationship problems.
    • Identify ways of rebuilding damaged relationships.
  • Positive vs Negative Aspect of Low Expectation

  • Interpersonal Attraction & Relationship Building

  • Lesson Summary
    • An expectation is a strong belief that something will happen. It is a presumed degree of probability of a chance. It can also mean the average probability of a chance occurrence.
    •  The positive aspect of low expectation ensures that one does not set him or herself up for disappointment by setting too high goals or expectations. The negative aspect of low expectations, on the other hand, thinks that having low expectations will unconsciously prevent you from succeeding.
    • Thinking is an intellectual exertion aimed at finding an answer to a question or the solution of a practical problem. Thought refers to the ideas or arrangement of ideas that result from thinking, the act of producing thoughts, or the process of producing thoughts. We have red thinking and green thinking.
    • The intellectual standards to evaluate thinking are clarity, accuracy, precision, relevance, depth, breadth, logic, significance, and fairness.
    • The overall flexibility of an organization as a system defined by a set of resources, processes, and managerial functions. Managerial flexibility, therefore, is defined as the entity's ability to change its policies, practices, or procedures quickly and easily to adapt to the diverse and changing needs of the environment.
    • The types of managerial flexibility are strategic flexibility, structural flexibility, operational flexibility, and internal and external scopes.
    • The different approaches for relationship building are the three-factor of love theory, Sternberg's triangular theory of love, equity theory, and social exchange theory.
